title: 106_hr1942
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that free trade agreements benefit citizens by improving income and prosperity through open markets. APEC's 21 member economies aim for free and open trade by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries. APEC's 21 member economies aim for free and open trade by 2020 for developing countries and 2010 for developed countries, representing over half of world production and global trade. This commitment is crucial for economic growth, creating new trade opportunities, and reducing trade barriers. The United States' strategic and economic interests in the Pacific Rim region rely on continued economic growth and stability through trade and investment opportunities. The financial crisis in Asia has disrupted the pattern of rapid US export growth in the region. The financial crisis in Asia has disrupted the rapid US export growth in the Pacific Rim region. Free trade agreement negotiations are crucial in achieving market opening measures for US goods and services amidst increasing pressures for protectionist policies. During the years 1989-1997, free trade agreement negotiations helped the United States achieve market opening measures for goods and services. Countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore have been allies in promoting economic growth through trade liberalization. Coordination with these countries is essential for building closer ties. Building closer ties and coordinating with countries like New Zealand, Australia, and Singapore, who are long-time allies of the United States in promoting economic growth through trade liberalization, will be beneficial as trade negotiations proceed in the Asia-Pacific region. The United States must continue to promote its interests in the region. The United States must continue to promote its interests in the Asia-Pacific region through aggressive trade negotiations, which will have immense payoffs as trade liberalization progresses in the next century. Bilateral trade agreement negotiations can positively influence multilateral and regional trade talks by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. The United States should pursue aggressive trade negotiations in the Asia-Pacific region to promote its interests. Bilateral trade talks can enhance multilateral and regional trade negotiations by expanding common areas of agreement on trade disciplines. This can lead to more effective resolution of trade and investment disputes with Pacific Rim countries. Trade and investment disputes between the United States and Pacific Rim countries could be more effectively resolved through mutually agreed-upon disciplines and dispute settlement mechanisms in free trade agreements. This approach can provide a firm foundation for enhanced cooperation and avoid issue-by-issue confrontations under trade remedy laws. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries aim to resolve trade disputes through agreed-upon disciplines and dispute settlement mechanisms, promoting enhanced cooperation and avoiding confrontations under trade remedy laws. These agreements enhance market access and understanding for US firms. Free trade agreements between the United States and Pacific Rim countries aim to enhance market access and understanding for US firms, stabilizing the bilateral trade balance and promoting mutually beneficial economic and political relations. The United States aims to enhance market access and understanding with eligible Pacific Rim countries through its trade policy. The United States aims to eliminate tariff and nontariff barriers through bilateral free trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, addressing regulatory barriers, foreign investment treatment, and intellectual property protection. The United States aims to address various barriers in trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, including lack of protection for intellectual property, discriminatory standards, and government measures restricting market access for US products. The United States aims to address barriers in trade agreements with Pacific Rim countries, including discriminatory standards, government measures restricting market access for US products, and unfair trade activities. SEC. 3. PRENEGOTIATION CONSULTATIONS. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will identify and consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If consultations show potential for a free trade area, a ministerial meeting will be requested within 60 days to discuss formal negotiations for a trade agreement. Within 60 days of enacting the Act, the President will consult with eligible Pacific Rim countries. If potential for a free trade agreement is identified, a ministerial meeting will be requested to discuss formal negotiations. The International Trade Commission will advise the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products from these countries. The United States International Trade Commission advises the President on the economic effects of providing duty-free treatment for products from eligible Pacific Rim countries within 6 months after ministerial meetings. SEC. 4. MINISTERIAL MEETING RECOMMENDATIONS. The President recommends establishing a council of public and private sector officials to review aspects of the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement. This includes analyzing trade practices, customs laws, and economic data harmonization. The President proposes creating a council to review the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement, focusing on trade practices, customs laws, economic data harmonization, and resolving disputes. A report on the overall relationship and prospects for a successful agreement is to be issued within 6 months. The President proposes establishing a council to review the bilateral relationship for a free trade agreement, focusing on trade practices, customs laws, economic data, and dispute resolution mechanisms. A report on the overall relationship and prospects for a successful agreement is to be issued within 6 months. The President will determine the feasibility and desirability of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible countries. The President will determine the feasibility of negotiating free trade agreements with eligible Pacific Rim countries based on reports from bilateral councils. The President will determine the feasibility of negotiating a free trade agreement with eligible Pacific Rim countries based on reports from bilateral councils. The determination will be based on the policy set forth in section 2 and the advice of the International Trade Commission under section 3(c), with a report submitted to the Committee on Finance of the Senate and the Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives. Factors considered in making the determination include the feasibility and desirability of establishing a free trade area between the United States and an eligible country. The President will consider factors like WTO membership, interest in bilateral trade agreements, and trade liberalization when determining the feasibility of a free trade area with an eligible country. A report will be submitted to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee. When considering a country for a free trade agreement, factors such as WTO membership, interest in bilateral agreements, trade liberalization efforts, alignment with US trade policy, and active participation in trade preparations are important. The country has an open economy, aligns with US trade policy objectives, and actively participates in WTO trade preparations. The country aligns with US trade policy objectives, actively participates in WTO trade preparations, and seeks harmonization of domestic and international standards. The organization is focused on eliminating export performance requirements, harmonizing domestic and international standards, increasing economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses, removing barriers to trade in services, providing national treatment for foreign direct investment, and accommodating market access. The country is increasing economic opportunities for small- and medium-sized businesses through deregulation, eliminating barriers to trade in services, providing national treatment for foreign direct investment, accommodating market access objectives of the United States, and resolving trade disputes with a clear intent to continue doing so. The bilateral trade relationship with the United States will benefit from improved dispute settlement. The United States aims to resolve trade disputes with countries that will benefit from improved dispute settlement mechanisms and enhanced market access for US products by eliminating trade barriers. The President must consult regularly with the House Committee on Ways and Means and the Senate Committee on Finance regarding the implementation of the Act. The Act defines "APEC" as the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum and "eligible Pacific Rim country" as a WTO member and a member economy of APEC.
